RANGE CONVERGENCE MONOTONICITY FOR VECTOR
MEASURES AND RANGE MONOTONICITY OF THE
MASS

arXiv:1904.05684v1 [math.CA] 11 Apr 2019

JUSTIN DEKEYSER AND JEAN VAN SCHAFTINGEN
Abstract. We prove that the range of sequence of vector measures
converging widely satisï¬es a weak lower semicontinuity property, that
the convergence of the range implies the strict convergence (convergence
of the total variation) and that the strict convergence implies the range
convergence for strictly convex norms. In dimension 2 and for Euclidean
spaces of any dimensions, we prove that the total variation of a vector
measure is monotone with respect to the range.

Contents
1. Introduction
2. Total variation and range
3. Convergence of the total variation and of the range
4. Zonal representation of masses
5. Perimeter representation of masses
Acknowledgement
References

1
4
14
19
24
27
27

1. Introduction
A vector measure Âµ maps some Î£â€“measurable subsets of a space X to
vectors in a linear space V [1, Chapter 1; 8; 13]. Vector measures appear naturally in calculus of variations and in geometric measure theory,
as derivatives of functions of bounded variation (BV) [6] and as currents of
finite mass [10]. In these contexts, it is natural to work with sequences of
finite Radon measures and to study their convergence.
The wide convergence of a sequence (Âµn )nâˆˆN of finite vector measures
to some finite vector measure Âµ is defined by the condition that for every
compactly supported continuous test function Ï• âˆˆ Cc (X, R), one has
Ë†
Ë†
Ï• dÂµ.
Ï• dÂµn =
lim
nâ†’âˆ X

X

2010 Mathematics Subject Classification. 46G10 (28B05, 52A05,52A39).
Key words and phrases. Wide convergence of vector measures; total variation; strict
convexity; zonoids.
J. Van Schaftingen was supported by the Mandat dâ€™Impulsion Scientiï¬que F.4523.17,
â€œTopological singularities of Sobolev mapsâ€ of the Fonds de la Recherche Scientiï¬queâ€“
FNRS.
1

2

JUSTIN DEKEYSER AND JEAN VAN SCHAFTINGEN

The strict convergence, which requires the total variation to converge also,
is an important concept that brings one back into a setting similar to tight
sequences of probability measures.
The total variation of a vector measure Âµ is defined in terms of a seminorm
|Â·|V on V by
|Âµ|V (X) , sup

(

X

)

|Âµ(E)|V : P is a finite Î£â€“measurable partition of X .

EâˆˆP

For real-valued signed Radon measures, V = R and the mass depends only,
up to a constant positive multiple, on the vector structure of the space V .
This is not any more the case when V is a finite-dimensional vector space
of dimension greater than 1 (dim V > 1). The norms on the space V are
all equivalent, but induce total variations whose values are not connected
mutually beyond the bounds given by equivalence of seminorms.
This lack of connection between various total variations is the starting
question of the present work. Reshetnyak [16] and Delladio [7] have proved
that strict convergence with respect to a strictly convex norm is a sufficient
assumption to obtain strict convergence with respect to any another norm
on V (see also [21] for the mass with respect to a Euclidean norm).
In order to characterize strict convergence through a topological object,
independent of a choice of norm, we propose to describe strict convergence
with the range of a vector measure Âµ, which is defined as 1
rg Âµ (X) , conv Âµ(A) : A âˆˆ Î£ .
In particular, when V = R, we have
(1.1)



rg Âµ (X) = [Âµâˆ’ (X), Âµ+ (X)],

where Âµ = Âµ+ + Âµâˆ’ , with Âµ+ â‰¥ 0, Âµâˆ’ â‰¤ 0, and Âµ+ and Âµâˆ’ are mutually
singular, so that for any widely converging sequence of vector measures,
the convergence of the range is equivalent with the convergence of the mass
[5, Appendix C].
In general, the range of a vector measure characterizes uniquely the total
variation of a measure [18]. This result is stable under convergence as the
range convergence implies in general the mass convergence:
Theorem 1.1. Let X be a locally compact separable metric space endowed
with its Borel Ïƒ-algebra B(X), let V be a finite-dimensional space and let
|Â·|V be a seminorm on V . If (Âµn )nâˆˆN is a sequence of Borel vector measures
from X to V that converges widely to some vector Borel measure Âµ, and
if the sequence of ranges (rg Âµn (X))nâˆˆN converges to rg Âµ (X) in Hausdorff
distance, then
lim |Âµn |V (X) = |Âµ|V (X).
nâ†’âˆ

The assumption on the convergence is described in terms of Hausdorff distance; this choice is in practice inconsequential: since the space V is finitedimensional, the Hausdorff convergence of compact convex sets is equivalent
1Classically, the range of a vector measure is deï¬ned [8] as the closure of the set

{Âµ(A) : A âŠ‚ X is Î£â€“measurable}. This deï¬nition coincides with ours as soon as Âµ has no
atoms [8, Corollary 9.5; 14]. Our notion has the advantage of being always a convex set
and is natural in view of the link between range and the total variation [18, Theorem 3].

CONVERGENCE AND MASS OF VECTOR MEASURES

3

to the Kuratowski convergence and to the convergence of the support functions [20, Corollaries 3A and P4.A] (see also [15]).
The converse statement of Theorem 1.1 does not hold in general. In fact,
the strict convexity of the norm appears as a necessary condition to have
range convergence:
Proposition 1.2. If the locally compact separable metric space X is not
discrete and if the seminorm |Â·|V is not strictly convex, then there exists a
sequence (Âµn )nâˆˆN of Borel vector measures from X to V converging widely
to some vector measure Âµ such that (|Âµn |V (X))nâˆˆN converges to |Âµ|V (X) but
(rg Âµn (X))nâˆˆN is constant and different from rg Âµ (X).
We prove that strict convexity is in fact a necessary and sufficient condition for the equivalence between range convergence and mass convergence:
Theorem 1.3. Let X be a locally compact separable metric space and (V, |Â·|V )
be a finite-dimensional Euclidean space. If the norm |Â·|V is strictly convex
and if (Âµn )nâˆˆN is a sequence of Borel vector measures from X to V that
converges widely to some vector measure Âµ, then
lim rg Âµn (X) = rg Âµ (X)

nâ†’âˆ

if and only if
lim |Âµn |V (X) = |Âµ|V (X).

nâ†’âˆ

The above result completely characterizes the strict convergence in terms
of range convergence. In comparison to mass convergence, the definition
of the rank depends on V only as a topological vector space, and does not
require any specific choice of norm.
The proof of Theorem 1.3 follows a more general approach due to Reshetnyak [16], relying on layerwise decomposition technique.
Theorem 1.3 shows that mass convergence implies range convergence in a
strictly convex setting. It is also known [18] that equality of the range implies
equality of the variation. This leads to the question whether the mass of a
measure depends monotonically on its range, that is, whether the inclusion
of sets rg Î½ (X) âŠ† rg Âµ (X) does imply the inequality |Î½|V (X) â‰¤ |Âµ|V (X).
In the case where the norm |Â·|V is Euclidean, we prove such a relation:
Theorem 1.4. Assume that V is a finite-dimensional vector space, equipped
with a semi-norm |Â·|V . If either dim V â‰¤ 2 or |Â·|V is Euclidean, then if Î£ is
a Ïƒâ€“algebra on X and the vector measures Î½, Âµ : Î£ â†’ V satisfy
rg Î½ (X) âŠ† rg Âµ (X) ,
then
|Î½|V (X) â‰¤ |Âµ|V (X).
If moreover the norm |Â·|V is strictly convex, equality in the above conclusion
occurs if and only if the ranges are equal.
In higher dimensions, we do not know if such relation still holds.
Open problem 1. If dim V â‰¥ 3 and if V is endowed with an arbitrary (respectively strictly) convex norm, is the mass (respectively strictly) monotone
with respect to range inclusion?

4

JUSTIN DEKEYSER AND JEAN VAN SCHAFTINGEN

Our approach to prove Theorem 1.4 when V is a Euclidean space directly
derives from the a representation formula
Ë†
(1.2)
|v|V = |hÎ·, vi| dÏƒ(Î·)
S

for some suitable multiple of the uniform measure Ïƒ on the unit sphere S of
V â‹† . We will prove that (1.2) implies the representation formula
Theorem 1.5. Assume that V is a finite-dimensional vector space, equipped
with a Euclidean norm |Â·|V , then for every Ïƒâ€“algebra Î£ on X, every vector
measure Âµ : Î£ â†’ V and every A âˆˆ Î£,
Ë†
|hÎ·, vi|(A) dÏƒ(Î·).
|Âµ|V (A) =
S

The representation formula (1.2) means that the norm is an L1 -norm in
the sense of Choquet [4, Paragraph 41], and that the unit ball of the dual
norm is a zonoid [2, Theorem 2.1; 4]. In the two-dimensional case, any
centrally symmetric convex set is a zonoid [2, Theorem 5.4; 4] and, in fact,
any norm has a similar representation for some positive even measure Ïƒ this
implies a counterpart of Theorem 1.5 for any two-dimensional norm. The
latter characterization of zonoids fails in higher dimensions: for example
the â„“âˆ norm whose whose dual â„“1 ball is hyperoctahedron, which is not a
zonoid.
In dimension 2, one has similar representation for any choice of norm,
and strict convexity translates by density of the support for the representing
measure Ïƒ.
When the vector space V is two-dimensional, we improve the geometric
interplay between range convergence and mass convergence, by drawing the
following link:
Theorem 1.6. Assume that V is a two-dimensional vector space, equipped
with a seminorm |Â·|V . If Î£ is a Ïƒâ€“algebra on X and if Âµ : Î£ â†’ V is a vector
measure, then

|Âµ|V (X) = 21 PerV rg Âµ (X) .

Here PerV (rg Âµ (X)) is the perimeter of the closed convex set rg Âµ (X),
computed with respect to the seminorm |Â·|V . When the target space V
is equipped with a strictly convex norm, the perimeter becomes strictly
monotone and Theorem 1.3 may be derived from Theorem 1.6. This kind
of isoperimetric inequalities for convex sets were also investigated in [12].
Theorem 1.6 is the extension of the one-dimensional formula |Âµ|(X) =
diam rg Âµ (X) that follows from (1.1).
For the two-dimensional case, Theorem 1.3 may be derived also from the
integral representation (1.2).
2. Total variation and range
2.1. Vector measures. We assume that X is a space endowed with a Ïƒâ€“
algebra Î£ and that the space V is a finite-dimensional vector space on the
real numbers. The space V âˆ— is the algebraic dual of V and hÎ·, vi = Î·(v)

CONVERGENCE AND MASS OF VECTOR MEASURES

5

denotes the duality product defined by the action of the linear form Î· âˆˆ V âˆ—
on the vector v âˆˆ V .
A vector measure Âµ : Î£ â†’ V is a countably additive function; when
V = R it is a (finite) signed measure. A vector measure Âµ induces definitions
of integrals
Ë†
Ë†
hg, dÂµi âˆˆ R.
f dÂµ âˆˆ V
and

for all Î£â€“measurable and bounded functions f : X â†’ R and g : X â†’ V âˆ—
and sets A âˆˆ Î£. These integrals satisfy for every E âˆˆ Î£ and Î· âˆˆ V âˆ— ,
Ë†

hÎ· Ï‡E , dÂµi = hÎ·, Âµ(A âˆ© E)i,

and

and the usual additivity, linearity and dominated convergence properties.
2.2. Total variation. The total variation of a vector measure is defined as
follows (see [1, Definition 1.4 (b)]).
Definition 2.1. Let Î£ be a Ïƒâ€“algebra on X. The total variation of a vector
measure Âµ : Î£ â†’ X with respect to a seminorm |Â·|V is the function |Âµ|V :
Î£ â†’ [0, +âˆ] defined for each set A âˆˆ Î£ by
|Âµ|V (A)(
, sup

m
X

|Âµ(En )|V : E1 , . . . , Em âˆˆ Î£, E1 , . . . , Em âŠ† A

n=1

and the sets E1 , . . . , Em are pairwise disjoint

)

.

The total variation enjoys properties that make of it a finite measure
[1, Theorem 1.6].
Proposition 2.2 (Finiteness). Let Î£ be a Ïƒâ€“algebra on X and let Âµ : Î£ â†’ V
be a vector measure. For every A âˆˆ Î£, |Âµ|V (A) < +âˆ.
Proposition 2.3 (Monotonicity). Let Î£ be a Ïƒâ€“algebra on X, let Âµ : Î£ â†’ V
be a vector measure and let A, B âˆˆ Î£. If A âŠ† B, then
|Âµ|V (A) âŠ† |Âµ|V (B).
Proposition 2.4 (Countable additivity). Let Î£ be a Ïƒâ€“algebra on X and
let Âµ : Î£ â†’ V be a vector measure. For every sequence (An )nâˆˆN of disjoint
sets in Î£,

nâˆˆN

We also have some algebraic properties:

Proposition 2.5 (Triangle inequality). Let Î£ be a Ïƒâ€“algebra on X and let
Âµ, Î½ : Î£ â†’ V be vector measures. For every A âˆˆ Î£,
|Âµ + Î½|V (A) â‰¤ |Âµ|V (A) + |Âµ|V (A).
Proposition 2.6 (Homogeneity). Let Î£ be a Ïƒâ€“algebra on X and let Âµ :
Î£ â†’ V be a vector measure. For every Î» âˆˆ R and every A âˆˆ Î£,
|Î»Âµ|V (A) = |Î»| |Âµ|V (A).

If X is a locally compact separable metric space, we endow it with its Borel
Ïƒ-algebra B(X). This topological setting on X is common when thinking
of C0 (X)â‹† as the space of finite measures on X, every finite measure being
Radon measures because X is second-countable and metric. In particular,
whatever the choice of the norm |Â·|V on V , the variation measure |Âµ|V is a
Radon measure.
Proposition 2.7. Let X be a locally compact separable metric space. If
Âµ : B(A) â†’ V is a vector measure and if A âŠ‚ X is open, then

|Î·|V â€² , sup hÎ·, vi : v âˆˆ V and |v|V â‰¤ 1 .

hÎ·, vi = 0. By the Hahnâ€“Banach theorem for seminorms (see for example [3, Theorem 1.1]), one has
|v|V = sup hÎ·, vi : Î· âˆˆ V â€² and |v| â‰¤ 1 .

(2.2)

Since V and V â€² are finite-dimensional, the suprema in (2.1) and (2.2) are
achieved in view of the Weierstrass extreme value theorem.
The proof of Proposition 2.7 is a transposition of the proof when V is
Euclidean and X is separable [1, Proposition 1.47].
Proof of Proposition 2.7. Let E1 , . . . , Em âˆˆ B(X) be disjoint subsets of A
and, in view of (2.2), let Î·1 , . . . , Î·m âˆˆ V â€² be linear forms such that for

thus by Lusinâ€™s theoremPthere exists a function Ïˆ âˆˆ C(A, V â€² ) such that

From now on, even if not stated explicitly, X will be assumed to be a
locally compact separable metric space endowed with its Borel Ïƒ-algebra
Î£ = B(X).
2.3. Range. The range of a measure has a definition that has some analogies with the total variation.
Definition 2.8. The range of the vector measure Âµ : Î£ â†’ V on a set A âˆˆ Î£
is the set
rg Âµ (A) , conv Âµ(E) : E âˆˆ Î£ and E âŠ‚ A âŠ† V.


Here, conv H denotes the closed convex hull of a set H âŠ‚ V . The range
defined by Definition 2.8 only depends on the structure of V as a topological
vector space.
P
If Âµ = ki=1 vi Î´xi , with x1 , . . . , xk âˆˆ X distinct points, then Definition 2.8
gives for every A âˆˆ Î£
rg Âµ (A) =

( d
X
i=1

)

ti vi : 0 â‰¤ ti â‰¤ Ï‡A (xi ) .

If X âŠ‚ RN is a Borel-measurable set and if Âµ , wLN , where w : X â†’ V is
a Borel-measurable function, then
(Ë†
f w dLN : f : X â†’ R is Borel measurable
rg Âµ (A) =
)
X

and 0 â‰¤ f â‰¤ Ï‡A in X .

It follows immediately from the Definition 2.8 that the set rg Âµ (A) is
a closed convex subset of the space V and that 0 âˆˆ rg Âµ (A). Moreover,
rg Âµ (A) = {0} if and only if Âµ = 0.
Since for every E âˆˆ Î£ such that E âŠ‚ A, Âµ(A \ E) = Âµ(A) âˆ’ Âµ(E), we
have rg Âµ (A) = Âµ(A) âˆ’ rg Âµ (A), that is, the set rg Âµ (A) is symmetric with
respect to the vector Âµ(A)/2 âˆˆ V .
In a finite-dimensional space V , the range is always bounded (see Proposition 2.2).
Proposition 2.9. Let Î£ be a Ïƒâ€“algebra on X. If Âµ : Î£ â†’ V is a vector
measure, then for every A âˆˆ Î£, the set rg Âµ (A) is bounded.
This property fails in general if the domain is not a Ïƒ-algebra [8, Example 8, Proposition 11].

8

JUSTIN DEKEYSER AND JEAN VAN SCHAFTINGEN

Proof of Proposition 2.9. Since V is finite-dimensional, there exist vectors
v1 , . . . , vd âˆˆ V and linear forms Î·1 , . . . , Î·d âˆˆ V â€² such that d = dim V and for
every i, j âˆˆ {1, . . . , d}, hÎ·i , vj i = Î´ij , where Î´ij denotes Kroneckerâ€™s delta.
P
In particular, we have for every v âˆˆ V , v = di=1 vi hÎ·i , vi, and thus, for
P
every set E âˆˆ Î£, Âµ(E) = di=1 vi Âµi (E), where Âµi (E) = hÎ·i , Âµ(E)i. For every
i âˆˆ {1, . . . , d}, the set function Âµi is a finite signed measure and thus by the
âˆ’
Hahnâ€“Jordan decomposition theorem it can be decomposed as Âµi = Âµ+
i +Âµi ,
âˆ’
where Âµ+
i â‰¥ 0, Âµi â‰¤ 0 are finite Borel measures [5, Appendix C]. Hence
rg Âµ (A) âŠ†

X

Ï„i vi : for every i âˆˆ {1, . . . , d}, Âµâˆ’
i (A) â‰¤ Ï„i â‰¤ Âµi (A)

i=1

,


and thus the set rg Âµ (A) is bounded.

The range is monotone with respect to the set, as was the total variation
(Proposition 2.3).
Proposition 2.10 (Monotonicity). Let Î£ be a Ïƒâ€“algebra on X, let Âµ : Î£ â†’
V be a vector measure and let A, B âˆˆ Î£. If A âŠ† B, then
rg Âµ (A) âŠ† rg Âµ (B) .


Proof. This follows directly from Definition 2.8.

Finally the range has a countable additivity property as the total variation
(Proposition 2.4).
Proposition 2.11 (Countable additivity). Let Î£ be a Ïƒâ€“algebra on X, let
Âµ : Î£ â†’ V be a vector measure and let (An )nâˆˆN be a sequence of disjoint
sets in Î£. Then
P

Here nâˆˆN rg Âµ (An ) denotes the set of finite sums of elements in the sets
rg Âµ (An ).
Since the range is compact (Proposition 2.9), Proposition 2.11 implies
that if A1 , . . . , Ak âˆˆ Î£ are disjoint, we have

Proof of Proposition 2.11. We first assume that v âˆˆ nâˆˆN rg Âµ (An ). Then

then follows that rg Âµ ( nâˆˆN An ) âŠ† nâˆˆN rg Âµ (An ).


The range operation is also compatible with the linear structure of vector
measures. First it is sublinear with respect to the sum of measures, as was
the total variation Proposition 2.5.

Proposition 2.12 (Triangle inequality). Let Î£ be a Ïƒâ€“algebra on X and
let Âµ : Î£ â†’ V be a vector measure. For every A âˆˆ Î£,
rg(Âµ + Î½) (A) âŠ† rg Âµ (A) + rg Î½ (A) .
The range is not linear. Indeed, in general one has rg(Âµ âˆ’ Âµ) (A) = {0} 6=
rg Âµ (A) + rg(âˆ’Âµ) (A).
Proof of Proposition 2.12. One has for every E âˆˆ Î£ such that E âŠ‚ A,
Âµ(E) âˆˆ rg Âµ (A) + rg Î½ (A). Since the range is convex and bounded (Proposition 2.9), the set rg Âµ (A) + rg Î½ (A) is closed and convex and the conclusion
follows.

The range operation is also stable under linear mappings in the target.
Proposition 2.13 (Linearity of the range). Let Î£ be a Ïƒâ€“algebra on X, let
V, W be finite-dimensional spaces and let Âµ : Î£ â†’ V be a vector measure.
For every T âˆˆ Lin(V, W ),


rg(T â—¦ Âµ) (X) = T rg Âµ (X) .
In particular, if Î» âˆˆ R and A âˆˆ Î£, we have
(2.3)

rg(Î» Âµ) (A) = Î» rg Âµ (A) ,

which is the counterpart of Proposition 2.6.
Proof of Proposition 2.13. If E âˆˆ Î£ and if E âŠ† A, then we have (T â—¦Âµ)(E) =
T (Âµ(E)). It follows then that
conv ({T â—¦ Âµ(E) : E âˆˆ Î£ and E âŠ† A})
= T (conv ({Âµ(E) : E âˆˆ Î£ and E âŠ† A})
We observe now that if the set H âŠ‚ V is convex and bounded, then by continuity and compactness in the finite-dimensional space V , T (H) = T (H). 
The topological structure on the space X can be used to characterize the
range by duality on test functions.
Proposition 2.14. If X is a locally compact separable metric space and if
Âµ : B(X) â†’ V is a vector Borel measure and if the set A âŠ‚ X is open, then

A

Proposition 2.14 is the counterpart of Proposition 2.7 for the range.

A

2.4. Links between the range and the total variation. In the onedimensional case, there is a straightforward relationship between the range
and the mass.
Proposition 2.15. Assume that dim(V ) = 1. If Âµ : Î£ â†’ V is a vector
measure and A âˆˆ Î£, then
|Âµ|V (A) = diam(rg Âµ (A)).
Proof. Without loss of generality, we can assume that V = R. Let Âµ =
Âµ+ + Âµâˆ’ be the Hahnâ€“Jordan decomposition (see e.g. [5, Appendix C]) into
measures Âµ+ â‰¥ 0 and Âµâˆ’ â‰¤ 0. One has then
|Âµ|(A) = Âµ+ (A) âˆ’ Âµâˆ’ (A)
and
rg Âµ (A) = [Âµâˆ’ (A), Âµ+ (A)],
and the conclusion follows.



In higher dimensions, the mass and the range are still related by a quantitative bound.
Proposition 2.16 (Comparison between total variation and range). Let
(V, |Â·|V ) be a seminormed space. There exists a constant C > 0 such that for
every Î£â€“algebra on the space X and every vector measure Âµ : Î£ â†’ V and
every A âˆˆ Î£, we have
rg Âµ (A) âŠ‚ BV (0, |Âµ|V (A))
and


|Âµ|V (A) â‰¤ C sup |v|V : v âˆˆ rg Âµ (A) .

CONVERGENCE AND MASS OF VECTOR MEASURES

11

Diestel and Uhl have a similar statement for the semivariation of a vector
measure in a Banach space [8, Proposition I.1.11].
Proof of Proposition 2.16. For the first part of the proposition, by Definition 2.1, for every set E âˆˆ Î£ such that E âŠ† A we have
|Âµ(E)|V â‰¤ |Âµ(E)|V + |Âµ(A \ E)|V â‰¤ |Âµ|V (A),
and the assertion follows from Definition 2.8.



Proposition 2.16 implies the continuity of the range with respect to the
seminorm induced by the total variation.
Proposition 2.17. If Âµ, Î½ : Î£ â†’ V and A âˆˆ Î£, then
dH (rg Î½ (A) , rg Âµ (A)) â‰¤ |Î½ âˆ’ Âµ|V (A).
Here dH (rg Î½ (A) , rg Âµ (A)) denotes the Hausdorff distance between nonempty compact subsets of V : if K1 , K2 âŠ‚ V are non-empty compact sets,
dH (K1 , K2 ) , inf Îµ > 0 : K1 âŠ† K2 + B(0, Îµ) and K2 âŠ† K1 + B(0, Îµ) .


Proposition 2.17 implies in particular that if the sequence (Âµn )nâˆˆN converges in total variation to Âµ on A, then the sequence of sets (rg Âµn (A))nâˆˆN
converges to rg Âµ (X) in Hausdorff distance.
Proof of Proposition 2.17. By the triangle inequality for the range (Proposition 2.12), we have
rg Î½ (X) âŠ† rg(Î½ âˆ’ Âµ) (X) + rg Âµ (X) .
By Proposition 2.16, we have
rg(Î½ âˆ’ Âµ) (X) âŠ† BV (0, |Î½ âˆ’ Âµ|V ).
We conclude then that
rg Î½ (X) âŠ† BV (0, |Î½ âˆ’ Âµ|V ) + rg Âµ (X) .
By symmetry, we also have
rg Âµ (X) âŠ† BV (0, |Î½ âˆ’ Âµ|V ) + rg Î½ (X) ,
and the conclusion follows from the definition of Hausdorff distance.



12

JUSTIN DEKEYSER AND JEAN VAN SCHAFTINGEN

A second property is the fact that the range determines univocally the
image: if two measures share the same range on a set A, then their total
variation on that set coincides [18].
Proposition 2.18 (RodrÃ­guez-Piazza). Let Âµ, Î½ : Î£ â†’ V be vector measures. If rg Âµ (X) = rg Î½ (X), then |Âµ|V (X) = |Î½|V (X).
The next lemma highlights the key property used by RodrÃ­guez-Piazza
to prove Proposition 2.18. It is an adaptation, in terms of total masses,
of a representation principle for the norm by finite combination of positive
values of linear functionals [18, Lemma 2].
Lemma 2.19. Let |Â·|V be a seminorm on V . For each Îµ > 0, there exists
Î·1 , . . . , Î·m âˆˆ V â€² and Î±1 , . . . , Î±m âˆˆ {âˆ’1, 1} such that, for every Î£â€“algebra on
the space X and every vector measure Âµ : Î£ â†’ V , we have
|Âµ|V (A) âˆ’

m
X

Î±i |hÎ·i , Âµi|(A) â‰¤ Îµ|Âµ|V (A).

i=1

RodrÃ­guez-Piazzaâ€™s Proposition 2.18 can be deduced immediately from

Proof of Proposition 2.18. Let Îµ > 0 and let then Î·1 , . . . , Î·m âˆˆ V â€² and

since Îµ > 0 is arbitrary, the conclusion follows.



2.5. Wide convergence. The notion of wide convergence of measures is
classically defined by testing the measure against compactly supported functions.
Definition 2.20. Let X be a locally compact separable metric space. A
sequence of vector measures (Âµn )nâˆˆN from X to V converges widely to some
vector measure Âµ whenever for every Ï• âˆˆ Cc (X),
Ë†
Ë†
Ï• dÂµ.
Ï• dÂµn =
lim
nâ†’âˆ X

X

The wide convergence is compatible with the linear structure of V . If
T âˆˆ Lin(V, W ) and if the sequence (Âµn )nâˆˆN converges widely to Âµ, then
(T â—¦ Âµn )nâˆˆN converges widely to T â—¦ Âµ.
A classical result is the lower semicontinuity of the mass under weak
convergence.
Proposition 2.21. Let X be a locally compact separable metric space and let
(V, |Â·|V ) be a seminormed finite-dimensional space. If (Âµn )nâˆˆN is a sequence
of vector measures from X to V widely converging to some vector measure
Âµ : B(X) â†’ V , then
|Âµ|V (X) â‰¤ lim inf |Âµn |V (X).

nâ†’âˆ
â€²
Proof. Let Ïˆ âˆˆ Cc (X, V ) and assume that |Ïˆ|V â€² â‰¤ 1 everywhere in X.

By

Ë†

and thus, in view of Definition 2.20

X

nâ†’âˆ

We conclude by Proposition 2.7.



In order to have an analogue for the range, we define the Kuratoswki
lower limit of a sequence of set.
Definition 2.22. The Kuratowski lower limit of a sequence (Cn )nâˆˆN of subsets of V is defined as
lim inf Cn ,
nâ†’âˆ

n

lim xn : the sequence (xn )nâˆˆN converges in V
o
and for every n âˆˆ N, xn âˆˆ Cn .

nâ†’âˆ

14

JUSTIN DEKEYSER AND JEAN VAN SCHAFTINGEN

By a diagonal argument, the Kuratowski lower limit lim inf nâ†’âˆ Cn is
always a closed set. Moreover, if Cn is convex for every n âˆˆ N, then the
Kuratowski lower limit lim inf nâ†’âˆ Cn is convex. Similarly, if for every n âˆˆ
N, 0 âˆˆ Cn , then 0 âˆˆ lim inf nâ†’âˆ Cn .
Proposition 2.23 (Weak lower-semi continuity of the range). If (Âµn )nâˆˆN
is a sequence of vector measures from X to V that converges widely to some
vector measure Âµ : B(X) â†’ V , then
rg Âµ (X) âŠ† lim inf rg Âµn (X) .
nâ†’âˆ

Moreover, for every Îµ > 0, if n âˆˆ N is large enough
rg Âµ (X) âŠ† rg Âµn (X) + B(0, Îµ).
In general, the inclusion is strict. Indeed if the space X is not discrete
and V 6= {0}, there exists a point x âˆˆ X and a sequence (xn )nâˆˆN in X \ {x}
converging to x. If v âˆˆ V \ {0}, the sequence (vÎ´x âˆ’ vÎ´xn )nâˆˆN converges
widely to 0, but the range of any of its terms is [âˆ’v, v] while the range of
the limit is 0, so that the inclusion is strict.
Proof of Proposition 2.23. For every Ï• âˆˆ Cc (X, [0, 1]), we observe that for
every n âˆˆ N, in view of Proposition 2.14
Ë†
Ï• dÂµn âˆˆ rg Âµn (X)
lim
nâ†’âˆ X

Hence in view of Definitions 2.20 and 2.22, we have
Ë†
Ë†
Ï• dÂµn âˆˆ lim inf rg Âµn (X) .
Ï• dÂµ = lim
X

nâ†’âˆ X

nâ†’âˆ

Since the Kuratowski lower limit lim inf nâ†’âˆ rg Âµn (X) is closed and convex,
the conclusion follows from Proposition 2.14.
For the additional assertion, let Îµ > 0. Since the set rg Âµ (X) is compact,
there exists a finite set F âŠ† rg Âµ (X) such that
(2.4)

rg Âµ (X) âŠ† F + B(0, Îµ/2).

Since the set F is finite, by the first part of the proof, when n âˆˆ N is large
enough
(2.5)

F âŠ‚ rg Âµn (X) + B(0, Îµ/2)

and thus by (2.4) and (2.5) we have
(2.6)

rg Âµ (X) âŠ† rg Âµn (X) + B(0, Îµ).



3. Convergence of the total variation and of the range
We consider in this section the relationship, for widely converging sequences between convergence of the range and convergence of the total variation.

CONVERGENCE AND MASS OF VECTOR MEASURES

15

3.1. Range convergence implies mass convergence. If a sequence of
vector measures converges widely and if its ranges converge, then its total
variations converge.
Proof of Theorem 1.1. We fix Îµ âˆˆ (0, 1) and we let Î·1 , . . . , Î·m âˆˆ V â€² and
Î±1 , . . . , Î±m âˆˆ R be given by Lemma 2.19, so that
(1âˆ’Îµ)|Âµn |V (X) â‰¤ (1+Îµ)|Âµ|V (X)+

m
X

Î±i |hÎ·i , Âµi|V (X) âˆ’ Î±i |hÎ·i , Âµn i|V (X) .

i=1

We observe that for every n âˆˆ N and every i âˆˆ {1, . . . , m},
diam(hÎ·i , rg Âµn (X)i) âˆ’ diam(hÎ·i , rg Âµn (X)i)
â‰¤ 2 |Î·i |V â€² dH (rg Âµn (X) , rg Âµ (X)).
By Proposition 2.21 and by Proposition 2.15, we have, as n â†’ âˆ,
|hÎ·i , Âµn i|V (X) = diam(hÎ·i , rg Âµn (X)i)
â†’ diam(hÎ·i , rg Âµ (X)i) = |hÎ·i , Âµi|V (X).
If Îµ < 1, it follows that
lim sup |Âµn |V (X) â‰¤
nâ†’âˆ

1+Îµ
|Âµ|V (X).
1âˆ’Îµ


The conclusion follows by letting Îµ â†’ 0.

3.2. One-dimensional case. When dim V = 1, the convergence of the
range is equivalent to the convergence of the total variation.
Proposition 3.1. Let X be a locally compact separable metric space and
let V be a one-dimensional space. Let (Âµn )nâˆˆN be sequence from X to V
converging widely to some vector measure Âµ. If
lim sup |Âµn |(X) â‰¤ |Âµ|(X),
nâ†’âˆ



then the sequence rg Âµn (X) nâˆˆN converges to rg Âµ (X) in Hausdorff distance.
Proof. Let Îµ > 0. By Proposition 2.23, if n âˆˆ N is large enough, we have
rg Âµ (X) âŠ† rg Âµn (X) + B(0, Îµ).

(3.1)
It follows then that
(3.2)

rg Âµn (X) âŠ† rg Âµ (X)
 

+ B 0, Îµ + diam(rg Âµn (X)) âˆ’ diam(rg Âµ (X)) + .
The conclusion follows from (3.1) and (3.2) since Îµ > 0 is arbitrary.



A corollary of the one dimensional case described above in Proposition 3.1
is the following equivalence criterion for range convergence, in terms of
masses of projection measures:

16

JUSTIN DEKEYSER AND JEAN VAN SCHAFTINGEN

Corollary 3.2. Let (Âµn )nâˆˆN be a sequence of vector measures. The sequence
(rg Âµn (X))nâˆˆN converges to rg Âµ (X) in Hausdorff distance if, and only if,
for every Î· âˆˆ V â€² ,
lim sup |hÎ·, Âµn i|(X) â‰¤ |hÎ·, Âµi|(X).
nâ†’âˆ

Proof. Let Îµ > 0. For every Î· âˆˆ V â€² , the sequence (hÎ·, Âµn i)nâˆˆN of signed
measures converges widely to the signed measure hÎ·, Âµi. By Proposition 3.1,
we have then


lim dH rghÎ·i , Âµn i (X) , rghÎ·i , Âµi (X) = 0.

(3.3)

nâ†’âˆ

Since the set rg Âµ (X) âŠ‚ V is compact and convex, there exist Î·1 , . . . , Î·m âˆˆ
V â€² and Î´ > 0 such that


(3.4)

rg Âµ (X) âŠ† v âˆˆ V : for each i âˆˆ {1, . . . , m}, hÎ·i , vi â‰¤ 1

and
(3.5)



v âˆˆ V : for each i âˆˆ {1, . . . , m} hÎ·i , vi â‰¤ 1 + Î´
âŠ† rg Âµ (X) + B(0, Î´).

In particular, if n âˆˆ N is large enough, we have by Proposition 2.13 and by
(3.3) and (3.4),
sup hÎ·i , rg Âµn (X)i = sup rg hÎ·i , Âµn i (X) â‰¤ 1 + Î´,
and thus by (3.5)
(3.6)

rg Âµn (X) âŠ† rg Âµ (X) + B(0, Îµ).

We conclude the first implication by combining the inclusion (3.6) with
Proposition 2.23. The converse claim of the proposition follows from the
fact that range convergence always implies mass convergence, and
|hÎ·, rg Âµ (X)i| = |Âµ|VÌƒ ,
where VÌƒ is the vector space V endowed with the degenerate norm
|x|VÌƒ = | (x, Î·) |.



3.3. Higher-dimensional case. In this section, we prove an equivalence
result between convergence of the range and convergence of the total mass,
when the mass is taken with respect to any strictly convex norm.
A seminorm |Â·|V is strictly convex whenever if the vectors v, w âˆˆ V are
linearly independent, then
|v + w|V < |v|V + |w|V .
As claimed in Proposition 1.2 stated in the introduction, strict convexity of the norm is necessary to enforce the convergence of ranges. The
proof of Proposition 1.2 we propose is based on an straightforward counterexample involving Dirac masses:
Proof of Proposition 1.2. Since by our assumption the seminorm |Â·|V is not
strictly convex, there exist two linearly independent vectors v, w âˆˆ V \ {0}
such that |v + w|V = |v|V + |w|V . Since the space X is not discrete, there

CONVERGENCE AND MASS OF VECTOR MEASURES

17

exists a point x âˆˆ X and a sequence of points (xn )nâˆˆN in X \ {x} that
converges to x. We define for each n âˆˆ N, the vector measure
Âµn , v Î´x + w Î´xn .
The sequence (Âµn )nâˆˆN then widely converges to the measure Âµ = (v + w) Î´x
and we have for each n âˆˆ N
|Âµ|V (X) = |v + w|V = |v|V + |w|V = |Âµn |V (X).
On the other hand the range of rg Âµn (X) = conv {0, v, w, v + w} while
rg Âµ (X) = conv {0, v + w} corresponds to the diagonal of the parallelogram
rg((X) Âµn ). Since the vectors v and w are linearly independent, the sequence
of ranges does not converge.

In particular, by Proposition 1.2 and Proposition 3.1 there exists a linear
map T : V â†’ R such that the sequence (|T â—¦ Âµn |(â„¦))nâˆˆN does not converge
to |T â—¦ Âµ|(â„¦). That is, in contrast with wide convergence and with convergence of ranges, the convergence of total variations is not invariant under
linear changes of variables.
Theorem 3.3. Assume that X is a locally compact separable metric space,
and let (Âµn )nâˆˆN be a sequence of vector measures weakly converging to some
vector measure Âµ. If |Â·|V is a strictly convex norm on V such that
lim |Âµn |V (X) = |Âµ|V (X),

nâ†’âˆ

then the sequence of ranges (rg Âµn (X))nâˆˆN converges to rg Âµ (X) in Hausdorff distance.
The proof follows lines of thought from the work of Reshetnyak [16, Theorem 3], Since the approach requires some tools from measure theory, we
repeat the proof with explanations on how the tools are used, and we chain
the argument with Corollary 3.2 to obtain Hausdorff convergence of the
ranges.
Proof of Theorem 3.3. For all n âˆˆ N, let Ï‡Âµn be the indicator measure [16]
of |Âµ|V , defined as the unique measure
Ï‡Âµ : B(X Ã— S) â†’ [0, +âˆ)
acting on any continuous function Ï• âˆˆ C(X Ã— S, R) as
Ë†
Ë†


dÂµn
(x) d|Âµ|V (x).
Ï• x,
Ï•(x, e) dÏ‡Âµ (x, e) =
d|Âµ|V
X
XÃ—S
Since we are working with vector measures, and because the ranges and
the masses remain uniformly bounded for n âˆˆ N, we may pass to subsequences and assume without loss of generality that the sequence (Ï‡Âµn )nâˆˆN
weakly converges to some measure Ï. As in [16, Theorem 3], we are going to
prove that the limit Ï actually equals Ï‡Âµ , the indicator function of |Âµ|V . To
that purpose, we use [16, Theorem 1] to obtain a layerwise decomposition
(Ï‰, Î») of the indicator measure Ï [16], in the
 sense that Ï‰ : X â†’ [0, +âˆ) is
a positive measure and Î» : X â†’ M B(S) is a function such that for every
Ï• âˆˆ C(X Ã— S),
Ë† Ë†
Ë†
Ï•(x, e) dÎ»(x, e) dÏ‰(x).
Ï•(x, e) dÏ(v, e) =
XÃ—S

X

S

18

JUSTIN DEKEYSER AND JEAN VAN SCHAFTINGEN

Moreover, for this layerwise decomposition, the function
Ë†
e dÎ»(x, e)
x âˆˆ X 7â†’ u(x) =
S

is B(X)-measurable and for every A âˆˆ B(X),
Ë† Ë†
Ë†

The strict convexity of the norm |Â·|V may be used to observe that in fact,
Î»(x, Â·) is a Dirac mass at u(x), for |Âµ|V -almost-all x âˆˆ X. Indeed, this

Ë†

Theorem 1.1 and Theorem 3.3 imply immediately Theorem 1.3.
4. Zonal representation of masses
In this section, we develop a geometric approach to manage the relation
between range convergence and mass convergence. Although the geometric
approach will give much less results when dim(V ) â‰¥ 3, it provides an interesting geometric point of view of the relation between mass convergence
and strict convergence when dim(V ) = 2.
4.1. Zonal representation formula. We will show that seminorms having a zonal representation have an associated mass that has an integral
representation.
Definition 4.1. A locally finite non-negative Borel measure Ïƒ : B(V â€² ) â†’
[0, +âˆ] is a zonal representation of a seminorm |Â·|V whenever
Ë†
|Î·|V â€² dÏƒ(Î·) < +âˆ,
Vâ€²

and for every v âˆˆ V ,
|v|V =

Ë†

|hÎ·, vi| dÏƒ(Î·).
Vâ€²

20

JUSTIN DEKEYSER AND JEAN VAN SCHAFTINGEN

As an example, we can consider the standard Euclidean norm in R2 and
the uniform measure Î½ on the unit circle S âŠ‚ R2 , giving
Ë†
Ë†
|v|2 2Ï€
2
|hv, ei| dÏ(e) =
| cos(Î¸)| dÎ¸ = |v|2 ,
2Ï€ 0
Ï€
S
and the zonal representation holds with Ïƒ = Ï€2 Ï.
More generally, every Euclidean norm admits a zonal representation.
Theorem 4.2 (Representation of Euclidean norms). If |Â·|V is a Euclidean
semi-norm on V , then it admits a zonal representation.
Proof. Up to a linear isometry and an orthogonal projection, we can assume
that V = Rd and |Â·|V = |Â·|2 is the standard Euclidean norm. Then we have
Ë†
|v|2 = Î± |hv, ei| dÏƒ(e),
S

where Ïƒ is the uniform surface measure on the Euclidean sphere S, and
Î± = Î±(d) > 0 is a normalization constant. The above identity directly
follows from the fact that the uniform surface measure is the unique (up to
multiplication constants) Borel measure on S that is stable under isometries
of Rd .

A norm |Â·|V has a zonal representation if and only if the associated unit
ball in V â‹† is a zonoid, which can be defined as the ranges of vector measure
[2, Theorem 2.1; 4].
If V is a two-dimensional space, every norm has a zonal representation
in the sense of Definition 4.1 ([2, Theorem 5.4; 4, 41.2]). This follows from
the fact that, in the plane R2 , every symmetric compact convex set may
be approximated by a symmetric convex polygon with is automatically a
zonotope in R2 .
For example, the usual Euclidean norm is represented by the uniform
measure on the dual sphere S of V â€² since the uniform measure is the only
(up to multiplicative constants) invariant measure under rotations and thus,
balls induced by its associated norm are Euclidean balls. This argument is
also valid in higher dimensions.
Another example is given by the â„“1 -norm on Rd defined for v âˆˆ Rd by
|v|âˆ ,

d
X

|v1 |,

i=1

which can be represented with Ïƒ =

Pd

i=1 Î´Î·i , where Î·i (v1 , . . . , vd ) = vi .

In higher dimensions dim V â‰¥ 3, there are some norms that do not have
a zonal representation. If v = (v1 , . . . , vd ) âˆˆ Rd , then
|v|âˆ = max{|v1 |, . . . , |vd |}.
has no zonal representation of the form Definition 4.1 by any positive measure Ïƒ. Indeed, if such measure Ïƒ existed, then its dual ball, which is the
â„“1 â€“ball, should be a zonotope. However, the 1â€“ball is a hyperoctahedron,
which has some 2â€“dimensional that are triangles, and is thus not a zonotope
[2, Theorem 3.3].

CONVERGENCE AND MASS OF VECTOR MEASURES

21

The above example is not related with the fact that the â„“1 and â„“âˆ norms
are not strictly convex. In fact, there are also strictly convex norms that
are do not have a zonal representation Definition 4.1. Indeed, in R3 , the
log 3
pâ€“norm does not have a zonal representation, if p â‰¥ log
3 , and for every
2

p > 2 it is known that the pâ€“norm does not have a zonal representation is
the dimension is large enough [2, (32); 23, Proposition 2].
Remark 4.3. If Ïƒ â€² : B(V â€² ) â†’ [0, +âˆ) is a measure such that for every Borel
cone C âˆˆ B(V â€² ), Ïƒ â€² (C) = Ïƒ(C), then for every v âˆˆ V ,
Ë†
Ë†
â€²
|hÎ·, vi| dÏƒ(Î·)
|hÎ·, vi| dÏƒ (Î·) =
Vâ€²

Vâ€²

and for every vector measure Âµ : Î£ â†’ V ,
Ë†
Ë†
|hÎ·, Âµi|(A) dÏƒ(Î·).
|hÎ·, Âµi|(A) dÏƒ â€² (Î·) =
Vâ€²

Vâ€²

In particular, the measure Ïƒ satisfying the assumption of Lemma 4.4 is not
unique; a canonical representative can be given by requiring sigma to be an
even measure supported on the unit sphere of V â€² .
The existence of zonal representation of the norm in V automatically
implies a similar representation formula for the mass. It may be seen as
an alternative way of representing the mass, without relying on layerwise
decompositions.
Lemma 4.4 (Representation of the mass). If Ïƒ : B(V â€² ) â†’ R+ is a zonal
representation of |Â·|V , then for every Ïƒâ€“algebra Î£ on X, every vector measure

Proof. If E1 , . . . , Em âˆˆ Î£ are disjoints subsets of A, we have
Ë† X



4.2. Application to monotonicity and convergence. When V is equipped
with an Euclidean norm the monotony of the mass with respect to range
inclusion, Theorem 1.4 stated in the introduction, is a direct consequence of
the zonal representation, Lemma 4.4.
Because of the particular structure of two-dimensional vector spaces, the
proof we give also holds for any norm on V whenever dim V = 2.
Proof of Theorem 1.4. Given two vector measures Âµ, Î½ such that
rg Âµ (X) âŠ† rg Î½ (X) ,
we clear have, for all Î· âˆˆ S:
hÎ·, rg Âµ (X)i âŠ† hÎ·, rg Î½ (X)i.
Since the range commutes with linear maps, we directly obtain, for all Î· âˆˆ S:
rghÎ·, Âµi (X) âŠ† rghÎ·, Î½i (X) .
Since the measures hÎ·, Âµi and hÎ·, Î½i are real-valued, we obtain
|hÎ·, Âµi| â‰¤ |hÎ·, Î½i|,

CONVERGENCE AND MASS OF VECTOR MEASURES

23

for all Î· âˆˆ S. Since V is Euclidean or dim V = 2, this implies, by Lemma 4.4,
|Âµ|V (X) â‰¤ |Î½|V (X). If the norm is strictly convex, then the inequality is
strict.

Relying on the integral and perimeter formulae obtained above, we also
propose an alternative proof of Theorem 1.3.
We first draw a link between the support of a zonal representation and
strict convexity. The above characterization will turn out to be particularly
efficient in dimension 2.
Definition 4.5. A zonal representation Ïƒ : B(V â€² ) â†’ [0, +âˆ] of a seminorm
|Â·|V is non-degenerate whenever for every non-empty double cone C âŠ‚ V ,
Ïƒ(C) > 0.
We recall that the set C âŠ‚ V â€² is an open cone whenever for every Î» âˆˆ
R \ {0} and x âˆˆ, Î»C = C.
In dimension 2, the non-degeneracy of the zonal representation is equivalent to strict convexity. This will turn out to be false in higher dimensions.
Proposition 4.6. Let V be a finite-dimensional space. Assume that Ïƒ is a
zonal representation of the seminorm |Â·|V . The norm |Â·|V is strictly convex
if and only if for every linearly independent vectors v, w âˆˆ V , there exists
Î· âˆˆ supp(Ïƒ) such that hÎ·, vi and hÎ·, wi do not have the same sign.
In particular, if V is a 2-dimensional vector space, then the norm is strictly
convex if, and only if, Ïƒ is non-degenerate.
Proof of Proposition 4.6. We observe that for every Î· âˆˆ V â€² and v âˆˆ V , we
have
hÎ·, vi + hÎ·, wi â‰¥ hÎ·, vi + hÎ·, wi ,
with equality if and only if the numbers hÎ·, vi and hÎ·, wi have the same sign.
We have
Ë†
hÎ·, vi + hÎ·, wi dÏƒ(Î·)
|v + w|V =
â€²
Ë†
Ë†V
hÎ·, wi dÏƒ(Î·) = |v|V + |w|V ,
hÎ·, vi dÏƒ(Î·) +
â‰¥
Vâ€²

Vâ€²

with equality if and only if hÎ·, vi and hÎ·, wi have the same sign for every
Î· âˆˆ supp Ïƒ, since the map z âˆˆ V â€² 7â†’ hÎ·, zi is continuous.
In particular, if Ïƒ is a non-degenerate zonal representation, then the norm
|Â·|V is strictly convex. In the two-dimensional case dim V = 2, the separation condition of Proposition 4.6 on the support conversely implies the
density condition on the support. Indeed, for every Î· âˆˆ V â€² and every Î´ > 0,
there exists v, w âˆˆ V such that if Î· â€² âˆˆ V â€² and hÎ· â€² , vi â‰¤ 0 â‰¤ hÎ· â€² , wi, then

|Î· âˆ’ Î· â€² |V â€² â‰¤ Î´.
Density of the support for a zonal representation of a strictly convex norm
in higher dimensions dim V â‰¥ 3 fails in general. As an example, one can
consider V = R3 and the measure Ïƒ = Ïƒx,y + Ïƒx,z + Ïƒz,y , where Ïƒx,y is the
uniform measure on the circle orthogonal to the y-axis; and similarly for
Ïƒx,z and Ïƒz,y . Then the support supp(Ïƒ) is far from being dense in S, but

24

JUSTIN DEKEYSER AND JEAN VAN SCHAFTINGEN

the induced norm
Ë†
p
p
p
hÎ·, vi dÏƒ(Î·) = v1 2 + v2 2 + v1 2 + v3 2 + v2 2 + v3 2 .
S

is strictly convex.

We know give another proof of Theorem 1.3 by mean of zonal integral
representation. We restrict ourselves to the case of Euclidean norms in the
case dim V â‰¥ 3, and strictly convex norms in the case dim V = 2.
Second proof of Theorem 1.3, by zonal representation. We shall only need
to prove that mass convergence implies convergence of the range, as the
converse statement holds in all generality.
For every Î· âˆˆ V â€² , the sequence (hÎ·, Âµn i)nâˆˆN converges widely to (hÎ·, Âµi)
and by Proposition 2.21, we have
(4.6)

every v âˆˆ V ,

By homogeneity, this still holds for every Î· âˆˆ V â€² and the conclusion follows
then from Corollary 3.2.

5. Perimeter representation of masses
5.1. Perimeter formula. So far, we have used zonal representation of
norms in spaces of dimension 2 to approach the problem of mass convergence
from a geometric point of view. In particular, we were able to characterize
strict convexity of the norm through density of the support for the measure
representing the norm.
We now give further geometric insight of the problem, by interpreting the
total mass of a vector valued measure as the perimeter of its range (up to
some multiplicative constant).
We first define the perimeter of a polygon in a two-dimensional space.
Definition 5.1. If dim V = 2 and P âŠ‚ V if P is a polygon of vertices
v1 , . . . , vâ„“ , we define its perimeter as
PerV (P ) ,

â„“
X
i=1

|vâ„“ âˆ’ vâ„“âˆ’1 |V ,

CONVERGENCE AND MASS OF VECTOR MEASURES

25

with the convention that v0 = vâ„“ .
This notion of perimeter is analogous to the notion of perimeter in crystalline variational problems [9, 11, 22, 24].
The perimeter of convex polygons is monotone with respect to set inclusion.
Lemma 5.2. If dim V = 2 and P1 âŠ† P2 âŠ‚ V are convex polygons, then
PerV (P1 ) â‰¤ PerV (P2 ).
Proof. Let H âŠ‚ V be a half-plane such that P1 âŠ‚ H and âˆ‚H contains one
side of âˆ‚P1 . Then by the triangle inequality for the seminorm PerV (Hâˆ©P2 ) â‰¤
PerV (H). By repeating this process on each edge of the polygon P1 , we reach
the conclusion.

Lemma 5.2 suggests to extend the definition of perimeter to convex sets
as the least upper bound of the perimeter of polygonal subsets.
Definition 5.3. If C âŠ‚ V is convex, we set
o

PerV (C) , sup PerV (P ) : P âŠ† C is a convex polygon .


In view of Lemma 5.2, Lemma 5.2 and Definition 5.3 coincide for polygons.
The monotonicity property of Lemma 5.2 can be transferred to arbitrary
subsets and the equality cases can be characterized for strictly convex norms.
Proposition 5.4. If C1 âŠ† C2 âŠ† V are compact convex sets, then
PerV (C1 ) â‰¤ PerV (C2 ),
If |Â·|V is a strictly convex norm and if equality holds, then C1 = C2 .
Proof. The inequality follows from Lemma 5.2 and Definition 5.3.
For the equality case, we assume by contradiction that C1 ( C2 There
exists v âˆˆ C2 \ C1 . Let H âŠ‚ V be a half-plane such that v 6âˆˆ H and C1 âŠ‚ H.
In particular, for every w1 , w2 âˆˆ C1 , we have since |Â·|V is a strictly convex
norm,
|w2 âˆ’ w1 |V < |w2 âˆ’ v|V + |v âˆ’ w1 |V .
We define
Î· , inf{|w2 âˆ’ v|V + |v âˆ’ w1 |V âˆ’ |w2 âˆ’ w1 |V : w1 , w2 âˆˆ C1 }.
Since the set C1 is compact and convex, we have Î· > 0. If P1 âŠ† C1 is a
polygon, then the polygon P2 defined as the convex hull of P1 and v satisfies
P2 âŠ† C2 and
PerV (P2 ) â‰¥ PerV (P1 ) + Î·.
By taking the supremum, it follows from Definition 5.3 that
PerV (C2 ) â‰¥ PerV (C1 ) + Î· > PerV (C1 ).



We establish Theorem 1.6 which states that
|Âµ|V (X) = 21 Per rg Âµ (X) .


This formula together with Lemma 4.4 yield a Cauchyâ€“Crofton-like integral
formula for the perimeter: for any compact convex set C âŠ† V :
Ë†
(5.1)
PerV (C) = 2 diamhÎ·, Ci dÏƒ(Î·).
S

26

JUSTIN DEKEYSER AND JEAN VAN SCHAFTINGEN

The proof of Theorem 1.6 is based on the following property of polygons.
Lemma 5.5. Let V be a two-dimensional vector space and |Â·|V be a seminorm on V . For every m âˆˆ N and v1 , . . . , vm âˆˆ V , one has
m
X

|vn |V = 12 PerV [0, v1 ] + Â· Â· Â· + [0, vm ] .


n=1

Lemma 5.5 implies in particular immediately that Theorem 1.6 holds
when Âµ has finite support.
Proof of Lemma 5.5. We proceed by induction. The identity is trivial if
m = 0. The induction step follows from the observation that
1
2 PerV

[0, v1 ]+ Â· Â· Â· + [0, vm+1 ] = 12 PerV [0, v1 ]+ Â· Â· Â· + [0, vm ] + |vm+1 |V . 




Proof of Theorem 1.6. If E1 , . . . , Em âˆˆ Î£ are disjoint subsets of A, then we
have
m
X

|Âµ(En )|V = 21 PerV [0, Âµ(E1 )] + Â· Â· Â· + [0, Âµ(En )] .


n=1

Since [0, Âµ(E1 )] + Â· Â· Â· + [0, Âµ(En )] âŠ‚ rg Âµ (A), it follows from the definition of
total variation (Definition 2.1) that
(5.2)

|Âµ|V (A) â‰¤ 12 PerV (rg Âµ (A)).

Conversely, if P âŠ‚ rg Âµ (A) is a polygon, there exist sets F1 , . . . , Fk âˆˆ Î£
such that F1 , . . . , Fk âŠ† A, Âµ(F1 ), . . . , Âµ(Fk ) are the vertices of P . Hence there
exists disjoint sets E1 , . . . , Em âˆˆ Î£ such that P âŠ† [0, Âµ(E1 )]+Â· Â· Â·+[0, Âµ(Em )].
It follows thus by Definition 5.3 that
(5.3) 12 PerV (P ) â‰¤ 12 PerV [0, Âµ(E1 )] + Â· Â· Â· + [0, Âµ(Em )] =

n=1

Hence by definition of total variation (Definition 2.1),
1
2 PerV (P ) â‰¤ |Âµ|V (A)

and thus by definition of perimeter (Definition 5.3)
(5.4)

1
2 PerV (rg Âµ (A)) â‰¤ |Âµ|V (A).

The conclusion comes from the combination of (5.2) and (5.4).



5.2. Application to monotonicity and convergence. Theorem 1.6 gives
a proof of the monotonicity of the range with respect to the mass.
Second proof of Theorem 1.4 when dim V = 2. We apply Theorem 1.6 and
Proposition 5.4.

As a final result, we give a proof of Theorem 1.3 in the two-dimensional
case, based on the perimeter formula, Theorem 1.6.
Third proof of Theorem 1.3 by mean of perimeter formula. If the set C âŠ‚
V is compact and convex, we define the function Î³C : V â†’ [0, +âˆ) by
(5.5)

Î³C (v) , PerV conv (C + {v}) .

We observe that, by the triangle inequality and the definitions, for every
v1 , v2 âˆˆ V ,

and that if 0 âˆˆ C,
(5.7)

|v|V â‰¤ Î³C (v).

references [7, 16].
